title: Everything You Need for Your Perfect Home Mindfulness Corner
author: Sam Lauron; Natasha Burton
description: When it comes to practicing mindfulness, it can help to carve out a dedicated space at home. Here are 10 top picks for your mindfulness corner.

But since the [COVID-19 pandemic](/health/coronavirus-covid-19) began, you might do more at home than ever before — including things like [working](/health/working-from-home-tips) and [exercising](/health-news/exercise-at-home-to-avoid-gym-during-coronavirus-outbreak) in addition to sleeping and eating. As a result, you may find it more challenging to manage stress, relax, and unwind after a day of working or handling other responsibilities. One solution, however, is to practice [mindfulness](/health/mindfulness-tricks-to-reduce-anxiety). Experts increasingly recognize [mindfulness](/health/mind-body/what-is-mindfulness) as a beneficial practice to incorporate into your daily life, often via meditation, yoga, or breathwork. In fact, the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)](https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/community/mental-health-non-healthcare.html) While you can practice mindfulness on a daily basis, regardless of location, carving out a space dedicated to mindful activities can help set the mood and make it easier to ground yourself. Below, you'll find 10 of our top picks for creating a calming mindfulness corner in your home or office. The perfect mindfulness corner will vary from person to person. Mainly, you want your corner to reflect your needs, as well as your personality and temperament. To make this space uniquely yours, opt for items in colors and styles that help you feel calm and centered. Generally speaking, you'll want to set up your mindfulness corner with items that will support your meditation practice. You might consider things like: - a rug or cushion to sit on - artwork you find soothing - plants to evoke a sense of the natural world - a [candle](/health/candle-meditation)or [diffuser](/health/best-diffusers)to create ambiance and provide [aromatherapy](/health/what-is-aromatherapy) To help you find the best pieces to include in your mindfulness corner at home, we searched for products with high ratings and positive customer reviews. Customers recommend the items you'll find below for their calming abilities, simple functionalities, and overall comfort. You can use it for a glass of water, a candle, or even a plant. But a table can also help you clear your area and keep clutter off the floor — and a tidy room [may help ease stress](/health-news/5-health-benefits-of-spring-cleaning). Most reviews say this side table is the perfect size for their small spaces. Pros - good size for small spaces - 4 colors to choose from - removable top tray - lip around tray edge keeps items from falling off Cons - removable tray not for everyone - too wobbly according to some reviewers Your own personal needs can help guide you in creating the ideal space for you. As a general rule, you'll want to limit distractions in your space, such as your phone and other devices, jarring noises, busy visuals, and bright colors. You might also consider building your mindfulness corner near a window to reap the benefits of natural light and outdoor views. If you don't have any window space, you can also connect with nature by finding a space near your [houseplants](/health/mental-health/plants-self-care). You'll want to opt for a quiet, safe space to be fully present. Choosing a spot in your house that doesn't get much traffic, like your bedroom, can help reduce the chances of someone walking in and disrupting your mindfulness session. Additionally, try to keep your mindfulness corner free of clutter and distractions. To reduce clutter, limit the items to what you absolutely need to facilitate your session. Aim to include only items in your mindfulness space that stimulate your senses and aid reflection — they might, for instance, promote calmness, allow you to center yourself, and help tune out any outside distractions. [Meditation](/nutrition/12-benefits-of-meditation), and a calming corner to meditate in, can do a lot of good for your well-being — but it's not always enough to [maintain mental health](/health/meditation-for-depression). If you live with chronic anxiety or depression and your symptoms don't improve after a few weeks, it may be time to consider reaching out for professional support. Some signs [you may want to connect with a therapist](/health/anxiety-symptoms#see-a-doctor): - Mental health symptoms begin to interfere with your daily life — including hygiene, school or work, and your social life. - Your feelings cause ongoing emotional distress. - You try to manage your distress with [substance use](/health/drug-abuse)or [self-harm](/health/mental-health/self-harm-alternatives). - You're having [thoughts of suicide](/health/depression/suicidal-thoughts). Need to talk? If you're having thoughts of suicide, you're not alone. You can get free, confidential support from compassionate crisis counselors by calling 988 to reach the [Suicide and Crisis Helpline](https://988lifeline.org/). If you'd rather not talk on the phone, you can text "HOME" to 741-741 to reach a crisis counselor at [Crisis Text Line](https://www.crisistextline.org/). You can access these free helplines anytime: 24/7, 365 days a year. How do you make a calm corner at home? Choose a space in your home that doesn't get much foot traffic where you can find peace without being disturbed. Add a few items that can help you meditate or find inner calm and stillness. Do calming corners work? Having a dedicated area to meditate or find peace can make it easier to stick with a daily mindfulness practice. What age do you start calming corners? It's never too early to start learning mindfulness skills. Even babies and young children can benefit from having a place where they can calm down or sit quietly. How do you use a calming corner? You can use your calming corner however you like. You may find it helpful to visit at a set time each day as part of a mindfulness routine, or take a few minutes in your space when you feel stressed or overwhelmed. That said, there are no rules, so do whatever feels right for you. The key to creating a mindfulness corner at home that's just right for you: Make it a calming environment that brings you peace, whether that means silence or soothing sounds, simple neutrals, or soft pastel shades. Your space can be whatever you want it to be. What really matters is choosing items that allow you to center yourself and tune out distractions, so you can reset and resume your day feeling grounded and recharged.
